data.title: Stop icon changes on hitting first breakpoint
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.0 insiders
- OS Version: macOS

Steps to Reproduce:
- start extension host debugging
- set and hit a breakpoint
  Observe: the stop icon changes from a red square to the crossed-plug icon.

Since the stop button really kills the extension host window, we should not use the 'disconnect' hover text and the crossed-plug icon but show the red square.

data.title: Terminal API: 'sendText' should be more specific
data.body:
The documentation describes it as `Send text to the terminal.`

The text is actually a command that is then executed by the terminal (once terminated by a new line).

I would suggest something like this without an `addNewLine` parameter:

``` ts
executeCommand(command: string): void;
```

What is a scenario where you want to append raw text to terminal? If there is one then I would suggest a separate function `append`.

data.title: .eslintrc.js does not have suggestions
data.body:
Refs #11100
1. Simple repo, initiazlie eslint, .eslintrc.js gets created
2. Open .eslintrc.js and triggere intelli-sense -> no suggestions
3. As found while discussing with @dbaeumer the issue here is that this file is .js and not .json
4. I would expect suggestions to help me set this file up

data.title: No eslint configuration found
data.body:
Refs: #11100
1. Init a sample workspace with eslint
2. Delete the .eslintrc.js file
3. Notice error 'No ESLint conifguration found'
4. I would expect a more user friendly message - something that would point the user to re-initialize eslint in this repository

![screen shot 2016-08-30 at 15 18 45](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1926584/18090462/21a795d0-6ec5-11e6-8040-6c8b0dfac4f7.png)

data.title: eslint: init command
data.body:
Refs: #11100 

eslint could contribute the global workbench command: 'eslint: init' which would run the `eslint --init` in the integrated terminal. This would make the setup experience more user friendly.

fyi @egamma

data.title: eslint github page does not have setup documentation
data.body:
Refs #11100

Our javascript docs page mentions how to setup eslint https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/languages/javascript
However the https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-eslint has no mention on how to set this up.

I would copy the documentation from our docs page to the github page, especailly since it is a first google hit for 'vscode eslint extension' query.

fyi @egamma @dbaeumer

data.title: Filter by filename or filepath in Git Changes Panel

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro

I think would be nice if we could filter changes in the Git Changes Panel. I work in a project that often we have a lot of changes in files that I don't want to commit right now. So I need to carefully choose files in Git Panel to adding them to stage. Here an example:

![git-panel](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2868031/18089926/a0f586da-6e98-11e6-8f21-ff2d0bd65abf.png)

I'd like to commit only gulp tasks in a project with 19 files changes. With an input text to input a filepath to filter (typing 'gulp' in my case - or just '*.ts'), I'll be able to select only the files that I want. Would be great for me.

data.title: Every restart of a node application is creating a new integrated terminal
data.body:
Testing #11091

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Clone [VS Code Smoke Test](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-smoketest-express) application
2. Create a Node debug launch to run the application
3. Use `integratedTerminal` as console in the launch
4. Start the launch
5. Restart the debug session

Expected: Node restart should happen on existing integrated terminal. 
Observed: For every refresh, a new terminal is being created.

data.title: Debug launch progress does not stop when launching using integrated terminal
data.body:
# Testing #11091

OS: OSX

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Clone [VS Code Smoke Test](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-smoketest-express) application
2. Create a Node debug launch to run the application
3. Use `integratedTerminal` as console in the launch
4. Start the launch

Expected: Progress should stop
Observed: Progress keeps running as if launching is in progress

![aug-30-2016 15-00-10](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10746682/18089919/7f5bba7e-6ec2-11e6-944c-dfacd7e3cf08.gif)

data.title: Optional methods in vscode.d.ts should be methods and not fields
data.body:
Regular methods in interfaces appear as:

``` typescript
provideWorkspaceSymbols(query: string, token: CancellationToken): SymbolInformation[] | Thenable<SymbolInformation[]>;
```

Optional methods appear as fields:

``` typescript
resolveWorkspaceSymbol?: (symbol: SymbolInformation, token: CancellationToken) => SymbolInformation | Thenable<SymbolInformation>;
```

It's supported, so I suggest to show them like:

``` typescript
resolveWorkspaceSymbol?(symbol: SymbolInformation, token: CancellationToken): SymbolInformation | Thenable<SymbolInformation>;
```

data.title: An Interactive Sequence Diagram Editor for VSCode
data.body:
At [WSO2](https://github.com/wso2) we are trying to build a new tooling platform using web-based technologies on top of VSCode. The initial requirement is to build an interactive sequence diagram editor for [WSO2 Gateway](https://github.com/wso2/carbon-gateway-framework/) for modelling integration workflows. 

We went through VSCode extension model and the existing extensions for available diagramming tools but could not find something similar to $subject. We found several options for integrating JS based sequence diagramming tools but they do not support interactive drawing.

The goal of this effort is as follows:
- Implement a new sequence diagram editor in JS and integrate it with VSCode. We have already started this and source code can be found [here](https://github.com/wso2-incubator/js-tooling-framework/tree/master/sequence-editor).
- Allow users to interactively draw sequence diagrams on VSCode. 
- Introduce [a new language](https://github.com/wso2/carbon-gateway-framework/blob/master/gateway-core/components/org.wso2.carbon.gateway.core/src/main/antlr4/org/wso2/carbon/gateway/core/config/dsl/external/wuml/generated/WUML.g4) for defining sequence diagrams and provide language support on VSCode may be using language server.
- Transform visual diagrams into sequence diagram definitions and save as files.
- Once sequence diagram definition files are opened in VSCode, render them in visual mode.
- Allow users to define the sequence flow in both source mode and visual mode.
- Integrate VSCode editor features with the visual representation of the diagrams. For an example debugging, opening up property windows for managing metadata of diagram elements, adding new buttons in VSCode for managing diagramming features, etc.
- Finally, make this tooling solution accessible on the web.

Q1: Would it be feasible to do this via the VSCode extension API?

Q2: If not will us be able to extend VSCode at the editor abstraction and integrate a new visual sequence diagram editor similar to [Monaco](https://github.com/Microsoft/monaco-editor)? 

Q3: Would it be possible to run VSCode on the web and make it accessible via a web browser?
We noticed that Microsoft has done this [at some point](https://channel9.msdn.com/Series/Visual-Studio-Online) but could not find much information on how to do it.

Really appreciate your thoughts on this!

data.title: returning LaunchResponse with success = false causes exception
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.4.0
- OS Version: Windows 7

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Start a debug session using the "vscode.startDebug" command with a valid launch configuration
2.  Return a LaunchResponse with `success = false`

The message of the raised exception is the same as the message of the returned LaunchResponse. Surrounding the `vscode.commands.executeCommand` call with a try-catch block did not resolve the problem.

data.title: Unexpected suggestion in debug console for variable named _
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.0-insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a node app, require lodash and assign to a variable named _ (e.g., var _ = require('lodash');
2. Set a breakpoint in code, type _ in the debug.console
3. Expect to see suggestions for lodash, instead see suggestions that contain an underscore:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1704059/18088261/91a53964-6eb1-11e6-8568-6bd799c2c406.png)

data.title: [BUG] VS Code
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.0.4 [version](http://s22.postimg.org/4mecb0dnl/screenshot_323.png)
- OS Version: Win8.1 64-bit home

Steps to Reproduce:
1. If you open the context menu of a file "VS code", in which you click on the file-referencing (href, src, etc.), will replace the current window.
2.  When you tap on 2x card through which you pop it open and then click on the linking (a href, src, etc.) will open in a new window (or rather the card).

Video:

[BUG - VS code](https://youtu.be/PjObXsQhKOA)

(sorry, for English - translated by google translator)

And thanks for fix.

data.title: Missing suggestions in debug console for err object
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.5.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a simple node app that uses lodash but do not install lodash
2. Run the app in the debugger
3. Get an error as the lodash module cannot be found.
4. Inspect the err object in the console. Expect to see intellisense for every member of err but only see one suggestion:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1704059/18087548/b2a07bbe-6ead-11e6-9aa2-97ffea62a2c4.png)

Note in the image above how I have previously typed err.message in the window but message is not offered as one of the suggestions when I type err.

Extension viewlet does not reflect runtime state of extensions

milestone.title: Backlog

data.body:
testing #11023:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.5.0-insider
- OS Version: macOS
- launch VS Code from command line with `--disable-extensions`
  Observe: extension viewlet still shows all extension with an uninstall button. There is no indication that extensions are not active.

data.title: Allow to disable extensions selectively
data.body:
The first thing I typically ask a user when an issue is reported is to run with all extensions disabled. However, if one extension is causing issues and 30 are installed, it is very hard to find the one causing the issue.

Ideally we have UI to disable an extension selectively (from the extensions viewlet) so that a user can easily find out which extension is causing issues. 

Optionally we could also allow to do so from the command line, e.g. "`code --disable-extension vscode-icons`"

CC'ing some folks fyi @alexandrudima @joaomoreno @jrieken @egamma
